ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Suppressing the spread length of threading dislocations in AlSb/GaSb superlattice grown on (001) InP substrate

Affiliation.OrgDivision: National Laboratory for Condensed Matter Physics, Institute of Physics
Microwave Devices and Integrated Circuits Department, Institute of Microelectronics
Engineering Research Center of Solid-State Lighting, School of Electrical Engineering and Automation

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Two designed structures of ternary Al0.5Ga0.5Sb and AlSb/GaSb superlattice (SL) buffers were prepared by molecular beam epitaxy. Double crystal X-Ray diffraction (XRD) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to characterize the material quality and observe the threading dislocation (TD) spreading behaviors. It was found that despite the wider full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the w-rocking curve obtained in the SL buffer compared with the AlGaSb buffer, the stronger the TD filter ability enabled the SL buffer to block the defects to beneath the thickness around 500 nm. This result suggests the AlSb/GaSb SL buffer possessed the superiority in the fabrication of antimony (Sb) based microelectronic devices.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Currently, Sb based III/V compound semiconductors are intensively studied for microelectronic applications due to the extremely high electron and hole mobility [1, 2]. For instance, there have been considerable interests in searching for the substitution of the Si channel field-effect transistors (FETs) with InGaSb channel complementary logic technology. High-quality dielectric interface and carrier mobility enhancement by strain have been recently demonstrated in p-channel InGaSb metal oxide semiconductor FETs [3–5]. Nevertheless, the lack of a semiinsulate (SI) GaSb substrate and the nature of a narrow band gap make carrier leakage a serious obstacle during the fabrication of GaSb-based FETs [6, 7]. Therefore, great efforts were devoted to explore heteroepitaxy of highly lattice mismatched Sb-based devices on SI GaAs and Si substrates [2, 8]. Aiming to accommodate such a large mismatch, some work has already reported on the epitaxy of the Sb-based buffer on GaAs and Si as well [9–12]. So far, a fully relaxed AlGaSb buffer of high Al composition, which was grown on the SI GaAs substrate was mostly applied as the buffer layer in most device structures [5, 13].

As is known,the lattice mismatch is 3.9 % for GaSb/InP and 4.5 % for AlSb/InP. However, there were rarely reports on Sb-based material grown on an InP substrate despite the smaller lattice match between InP and GaSb (or AlSb) compared to the GaAs substrate. On the other hand, several papers have reported the use of the SL buffer to optimize the crystal quality of material with a large lattice mismatch between the substrate [14–17]. But still no similar work was conducted in the GaSb/InP material system.
In this study, the AlSb/GaSb SL buffer was grown on SI InP (001). The property of such SL buffer was compared with the AlGaSb random alloy buffer.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para: Our two samples were produced by VG-80H solid-source molecular beam epitaxy system equipped with reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED). The degassed InP substrate was heated to remove the initial oxide layer at 530 ∘C in the ambient of As2 (a flux of 3–4×10−6 torr). The deoxidization temperature was calibrated by the point of surface reconstruction transition [(2×4)→(4×2)] monitored by RHEED. Then the temperature was decreased to 400 ∘C for the growth of a 20 nm AlSb nucleation layer. Afterward, the temperature was increased back to 530 ∘C to anneal the nucleation layer for 5 minutes and then a 1.5 μm Al0.5Ga0.5Sb buffer for sample A and a 250-periods 4.5 nm AlSb/1.5 nm GaSb SL buffer for sample B were grown to check the influence of the SL buffer on the crystal quality. At last, a 10 nm GaSb cap layer was deposited at 530 ∘C for each sample. All the samples were prepared under a flux of Sb4(3–4×10−6 torr). During the whole procedure, the beam equivalent pressures ratio of V/III elements was fixed at around 6.7 and the growth rate was 0.46 monolayer/second for both AlSb and GaSb. The growing rate was read from RHEED oscillations.

Two theta scanning and rocking curves of the double-crystal XRD (Bede-D1) were used to determine the material composition and evaluate the material quality. Cross-sectional TEM images were employed to visualize the TD propagation behaviors, which were taken from the [110] direction by a JEM-2010 high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) operating at 200 kV. The specimens for TEM observation were prepared by mechanical thinning, dimpling, and ion milling. The images were recorded with the electron-sensitive films followed by digitizing. The high resolution image was filtered in order to increase the resolution [18].

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The XRD (004) plane 2θ-scanning curve (in black) of sample A (AlGaSb buffer) and sample B (AlSb/GaSb SL buffer) are shown in Fig. 1(a) and (b). The simulation data (in red) was acquired from the Rocking curve Analysis by the Dynamical Simulation (RADS) provided by the Bede-D1 testing system, which is a program to calculate high resolution rocking curves for epitaxial crystal structures, and substrates using the fundamental X-ray scattering equations of dynamical diffraction. It was consistent with the predesigned compositions well: experimental Al0.53Ga0.47Sb for nominal Al0.5Ga0.5Sb and the obtained SL period of 4.3 nm AlSb/1.8 nm GaSb for designed structure of 4.5 nm AlSb/1.5 nm GaSb, respectively.
Fig. 1
Experimental (in black) and fitted (in red) XRD (004)-plane ω–2θ scanning curve of (a) AlGaSb/InP, (b) AlSb/GaSb SL/InP, (c) (004)-plane ω-rocking curves for AlGaSb (in black) and the zero-order peak of AlSb/GaSb SL (in red) was also displayed

Based on that, several groups have reported on the application of an AlSb initiation layer to improve the quality of the GaSb buffer grown on Si; an 20 nm thick AlSb nucleation layer was therefore introduced in our study [19, 20]. The thickness of 20 nm was not derived from any detailed experiments but randomly chosen at the very beginning of this material system research. Then the XRD (004) w-rocking curves were carried out to assess the crystalline quality of the two buffers, and the results were shown in Fig. 1(c). The FWHM of the w-rocking curve was 563 arcsec for the AlGaSb epitaxy layer and 623 arcsec for the SL zero-order peak. Both our two samples have a comparable FWHM value to the result obtained in GaSb/Si by Akahane et al., that is, the FWHM of the GaSb buffer would lie around 600 arcsec as the AlSb initiation layer was 20 nm thick [19]. However, obviously the SL sample had wider FWHM than the AlGaSb sample, which suggests a poorer crystal quality probably resulting from a higher mean density of XRD-sensitive defects. These phenomena may be explained as below: Firstly, the SL sample (a period of 4.3 nm AlSb/1.8 nm GaSb) possessed a higher equivalent Al composition compared to the nominal 53 % in the ternary AlGaSb. As is known, the lattice mismatch was larger in AlSb/InP than GaSb/InP and the mobility of the Al atom was usually lower than Ga atom. So, the epitaxial growth of AlSb was more difficult than that of GaSb. In other words, larger Al incorporation may cause material property degradation. Secondly, the optimized temperature (around 500 ∘C) of growing GaSb was well demonstrated [19, 21]. Nevertheless, there was no sufficient work reported on AlGaSb or AlSb. It should be wise to improve the substrate temperature to enhance the surface mobility of the Al atom, but a higher temperature may lead to the desorption of Sb resulting in a poor surface morphology [19]. So, the growing temperature of our two samples was fixed at 530 ∘C, which was the critical temperature that enhanced Sb desorption. This value was surely more favorable for the AlGaSb buffer rather than the SL buffer, which consisted of 250 repeats of pure AlSb layers. Thirdly, it was deduced that the effect of strain SL on TD filtering through introducing misfit dislocations or lattice distortion right at the interfaces was supposed to exist in our study and this effect would significantly roughen the interfaces in the SL. For the structure of SL, the FWHM was not only determined by the body crystal quality of each layer, but also the smoothness and uniformity of the interfaces were another major determining factor. To sum up, the three points above may all broaden the FWHM of the SL sample.

As is well known, the penetration depth of an X-ray can reach several μms in a semiconductor material. So, the rocking curve measurement delivered average information regarding the crystal quality throughout the buffer layer. In order to understand the defect evolution directly and visually, TEM images of both samples were taken and the results are illustrated in Fig. 2. Both in Fig. 2(a) and (b), it was clearly observed that a dense mass of defects were concentrated in both interfaces and bulk of the AlSb initial film (the sharp contrast indicated in TEM images) as in-plane strain (AlSb/InP) relaxing. It was quite like the case published elsewhere, that is, most of the defects were commonly localized at (or around) the interfaces of and in the AlSb nucleation layer for the high lattice-mismatch heteroepitaxy of the Sb-based material. Besides, there were still a great number of TD passing upward into the subsequent layer when the 20 nm AlSb layer finished. This may be attributed to the lack of special interface engineering and careful optimization of the AlSb nucleation layer.
Fig. 2
(a) TEM image (
$\mathit{g}=2\overline{2}0$ ) of cross-section of AlGaSb on InP, (b) GaSb/AlSb SL on InP. The inset picture in (b) shows a period of the GaSb/AlSb SL

Although a lot of TD deriving from the AlSb film propagated into both of the two buffers, an interesting phenomenon should be noted in Fig. 2, in which the distribution of the TD was quite different in the whole buffer. With increasing the buffer thickness, there was TD arising in the AlGaSb and they could penetrate straight upward and terminated at the surface. This phenomenon would drastically deteriorate the devices performance. However, the SL buffer exhibited a huge potential of solving this problem as proven in Fig. 2(b). The structure of SL played an excellent role as the TDs filter. Most of the TD tend to bend and merge together. When the SL thickness reached about 500 nm, almost all the TD were completely blocked. The multiple interfaces between AlSb and GaSb should have played an important role in deflecting the defects, and thus increase the possibility of dislocations to merge together. The TEM observation shows the distribution of TDs in the SL buffer is mainly far beneath the surface. So, the spread length of TD was largely suppressed in the AlSb/GaSb superlattice.

In addition, twin boundaries were observed during the TEM observation in the AlGaSb buffer layer. Figure 3 shows a HRTEM filtered image of a twin boundary; the top-left inset was the corresponding diffractogram. The resolution of the image was highly improved after processed through the method in [18]. From Fig. 3, we can conclude that twinning occurred on {111} facet and the angle between the twin crystal was 70.53∘. Unlike the AlGaSb buffer, there were no observations of the twin boundaries in the SL sample.
Fig. 3
Filtered image of the twin crystal HRTEM image from the AlGaSb sample (inset figure shows an electron-diffraction pattern)

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In conclusion, the AlGaSb and AlSb/GaSb SL buffer grown on InP was investigated. It was found that although the SL exhibited poorer material quality, most of the TDs lie far beneath the sample surface. However, in the thick AlGaSb buffer layer, some TDs can directly penetrate into the buffer layer. This result demonstrates the advantage AlSb/GaSb SL over the AlGaSb thick layer serving as the buffer layer.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: This work was supported by the Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 61106013, 61275107, and 11104226), the National High Technology Research and Development Program of China (Grant No. 2009AA033101), and the National Basic Research Program of China (Grant Nos. 2010CB327501 and 2011CB925604).
